awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an EEG for Examination of Brain-Behavior Relationships Across the Lifespan
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports the acquisition of an Electroencephalography (EEG) system (ANT Neuro eego mylab128-channel) to establish the first EEG laboratory for brain imaging at Eastern Michigan University (EMU). EEG is a non-invasive human brain imaging method that measures neural electrical activity in the human brain arising from thinking and behavior with millisecond accuracy. The EEG laboratory critically expands neuroscience training and research in the Departments of Psychology, Communication Sciences and Disorders, and the interdisciplinary Neuroscience Program (Psychology, Biology, Chemistry). The EEG laboratory also has a substantial regional impact on the institutional community. EMU is recognized as one of the most diverse universities in the Midwest. The EEG laboratory allows EMU to contribute to the broader aims of the scientific community to recruit, retain, and promote members of minoritized groups into STEM fields. The laboratory allows for workshops to train local and regional faculty and students on neuroimaging, serve as a catalyst for the development of research assistantships and fellowships targeted for underrepresented students, including those from rural communities, and be central in creating a mentoring partnership with the McNair Scholars Program for students interested in EEG research. The EEG laboratory enhances collaborative research efforts within EMU, with partnering regional institutions, and foster national collaborations in developmental neuroscience.

Knowledge of the brain mechanisms underlying fundamental cognitive and behavioral processes (e.g. attention and language) in infants/children and older adults, the precise timing of developmental changes, and knowledge of crucial environmental factors that impact this timing has lagged behind research with younger adults and remains a frontier of investigation. EEG is non-invasive and well-tolerated by infants and children. This team examines the EEG signals and developmental timing of key cognitive and behavioral processes including attention and working memory, motor control, self-regulation, sleep, and communication. EEG event-related potentials, frequency (power), and brain connectivity in developing neural networks are explored. The electrophysiological mechanisms (spectral power and connectivity) underpinning the development of the default mode and dorsal attention networks and orienting system in infancy/toddlerhood are examined to clarify the relationships between attention and social-communication. The neural correlates of change of bimanual and unimanual motor control across the lifespan as well as the neural underpinnings of inconsistent hand preference and hand dominance are being investigated. Investigators are examining developmental changes and environmental precursors of event-related potentials hypothesized to underlie self-regulation. Investigation of the functions of napping, including neurophysiology and behavior, in early childhood provide vital information on reciprocal relations between the development of sleep-wake regulation and the development of attention. Finally, few studies have examined the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying working memory-linguistic processes in older adults. EEG is being used to explore the long-term learning effects and the compensatory processes that occur in older adults.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, Eastern Michigan University (EMU) received a $149,919 Major Research Implementation (MRI) award entitled MRI: Acquisition of an EEG for Examination of Brain-Behavior Relationships Across the Lifespan to support the purchase of an ANT Neuro eego mylab 128-channel high-density electroencephalography (EEG ) for shared use across three departments/programs (Neuroscience Program, Psychology, Communication Sciences and Disorders) and two colleges (College of Arts and Sciences and College of Education). EEG, a non-invasive brain imaging technique, records the spontaneous electrical activity of the neurons in the brain. Broadly, the achieved project outcomes included the: 1) development of the Behavioral Research and Imagin Neurodevelopment (BRAIN) lab at EMU, 2) training of faculty and students in contemporary cognitive neuroscience methods at the human/systems level for the first time in the institution’s history, and 3) execution of faculty and student-led research projects testing sophisticated models to understand human behavior at an electrophysiological and systems level. Students had the opportunity to develop technical, theoretical, and conceptual knowledge for careers in neuroscience, psychology, and speech language pathology. Three of the PIs and their students have executed pilot investigations of: 1) attention/executive functions in preschool children (Lajiness-O’Neill), 2) motor control and hemispheric lateralization in adults (Bo), and linguistic-cognitive processes in adults (Hashimoto), while the agendas of the remaining faculty will be underway.

Lab Setup and Infrastructure: The Behavioral Research and Imaging Neurodevelopment (BRAIN) lab (https://www.emich.edu/psychology/labs/eeg-lab/index.php) is now a fully functioning EEG imaging lab for undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty at EMU. Given the original NSF award, the team was able to secure six additional internal and external awards totaling $34,833 to: 1) support the acquisition of additional image analysis lab equipment, 2) train faculty and students in event-related potential (ERP) analysis (the brain’s response to a sensory, cognitive, or motor event), and to 3) secure psychometric measures to execute the proposed areas of research.

Training and Instruction in Acquisition and Analyses: The team established the formal operations plan and developed a technical training method/manual to be used by subsequent generations of faculty/students. A BRAIN Lab open house was conducted to recruit faculty and students. Faculty and students developed a series of training videos for acquisition of EEG signals. Further training was undertaken on the use of EEGLAB and ERPLAB (preprocessing methods) under the direction of Dr. Yanni Liu (University of Michigan) and Dr. Emily Kappenman (San Diego State University). The team is continuing to develop statistical methods to examine differences in EEG brain networks across development. In addition to faculty, the lab has trained approximately 15 graduate students (clinical psychology doctoral and masters) and 11 undergraduates (neuroscience), with 27% representing racial and/or ethnic minorities. Within the lab, two doctoral students have been accepted into prestigious neuropsychology internship programs, three members have been accepted into medical and graduate school, and two have secured prestigious research study coordinator positions. Beyond the lab, the first Neuroscience seminar course (NSCI440) was conducted in winter 2023 focused on developing hands-on skills in EEG. The faculty are enrolling undergraduate students in independent research courses (PSY, NSCI, or CSD 497, 498, 499) for EEG training. The lab has its first Symposium Undergraduate Research Fellow (SURF).

Execution of Proposed Experimental Investigations: The core research interest among PIs is to examine age-related differences in brain-behavior across infants, children, and adults. Pilot investigations have focused on: 1) attention/executive functioning in preschoolers, 2) motor lateralization, and 3) linguistic-cognitive functioning in adults. Adult resting state acquisition and analysis methods were validated in the pilot study Understanding resting-state brain networks with electroencephalography (N=11). The study Neural correlates of executive functioning in preschool children (N=45) revealed that decreases in theta power in preschool children may be the first indication of expected maturational changes in resting-state EEG power (Lobermeier et al., 2025), with further analyses utilizing machine learning on resting state EEG to reliably predict intellectual functioning and risk status in preschool children born term or preterm (O’Neill et al., 2025). The pilot investigations, Laterality of motor behavior and its relationship with psychological outcomes and resting-state brain connectivity and Lateralization of motor behavior as a measure of executive functioning and resting-state electrocortical alpha activity (N=48), have revealed correlations between right-lateralized whole-brain frequency power (i.e., theta, alpha, and beta) and self-reported behavior regulation (Dillahunt et al., in preparation). The pilot study, Using EEG to understand phonological processes in young and older adults is underway to examine the influence of working memory on linguistic processes across the lifespan.

Summary: Our key outcomes include the: 1) successful launch and set up of the interdisciplinary EEG Lab, Behavioral Research and Imaging Neurodevelopment (BRAIN), at EMU, 2) successful and ongoing launch of training in EEG acquisition and analysis, and 3) successful launch of key neuroscience instruction and research agendas addressing attention/executive, motor, and linguistic-cognitive process across the lifespan.
